comms: The first NP is fronted, but this is not obligatory.
comms_internal: This sentence means 'Obsaa has pain at the moment of speech'. Alternative is "obsaa-n mata-bowwuu k'ab-a" [PN-NOM head-ache.ABS have-3SG.M.IPFV], which means 'Obsa experiences pain sometimes' (Y is incorporated).
The verb with a perfective suffix conveys the present sense.

comms: Not included in the database because the intended meaning is expressed by a structurally discontinuous combination (predicate + adnominal modifier).
comms_internal: The verb gah-e 'suffice' exists, but it is not appropriate for this specific context. Modifiers agree with the head noun by their case, number and gender. gahaa 'anough' is derived from the verb gah-e suffice-3SG.M.PFV
CV
The verb also occurs with the middle marker -at- as in obsaa-n tolaa moʔ-at-e [PN-NOM PN.ABS beat-MID-3SG.M.PFV] which emphasizes Obsa's winning.
The preposition 'gadi' literally means 'down'
Present continuous like in no. 15 does not work in this context.

The verb k'ak'k'ab- means 'catch-up with' and it is a transitive verb  (A fuller sentence would be "obsaa-n boontuu hordof-ee itti k'ak'k'ab-e" [PN-NOM PN.ABS follow-PFV.CONV LOC catch_up-3SG.M.PFV] ''Obsa followed and caught up with Bontu.'')

back_translation_en: ‘Obsa got to know Bontu a year ago.’
‘The boy is trying to catch the cat.’
‘Obsa is dreaming of a new car.’

comms_internal: kompaasii is not a genuine direct object (cf. the active double-object construction: Cf. an active sentence: "ani meeʃaa kana kompaasii-n dʒeɗ-aan" [1SG.NOM tool.ABS this.ABS compass.ABS-1SG say-IPFV.OBJ] 'I call this tool a compass.'). Passive is more nartural than general-agent construction. Alternative is "meeʃaa kana kompaasii dʒeɗaniin" [tool.ABS this.ABS compass.ABS say.3PL.PFV.OBJ] 'They call this tool a compass.'
Referring to PRESENT with the perfective verb form.
PASS

comms: The first NP is fronted, but this is not obligatory.
comms_internal: I wonder why the verb is indexed for 3SG not 3PL? The subject is, it seems, "ten birrs", but would not we expect a plural index in such a construction? (The pattern is DAT_NOM, cf. "birrii-n kuɗan naa-f haf-e" [birr-NOM ten.ABS 1SG.ABS-DAT remain-3SG.M.PFV] 'I have ten birrs left')
CV

back_translation_en: ‘No, my shirt is different from yours.’

sentence: obsaa-n ʃamizii isaa of irraa baas-e
comms_internal: with the reflexive pronoun in ablative
with the locative element ittiitti which represents something else in the discourse into which sugar was poured.

back_translation_en: ‘Obsa is squeamish about the dirty dishes.’

sentence: gurb-ittʃa boontuu irraa dʒaalalli isa k'ab-e
back_translation_en: ‘The boy fell in love with Bontu.’
comms_internal: Lit. 'The love for Bontu caught the boy'. Sometimes uses as gurb-ittʃ-i boontuu dʒaallat-e [boy-DEF-NOM PN.ABS love-3SG.M.PFV] 'The boy loved Bontu.'

isaa-f [3SG.M.POSS-DAT]  is glossed for POSS based on the preceding noun haaɗa 'mother' which is the possessum. In other sentences like in (no. 61) → isaa-f  [3SG.M-DAT] 'for him'. Hence, the genitive NP haaɗa isaaf 'for his mother' is a DAT constituent in this sentence.

back_translation_en: ‘Obsa has held a grudge against Bontu.’

back_translation_en: ‘Obsa is getting angry at his daughter.’
